meanings.def: the time of day when light first appears
examples: at dawn They start work at dawn.
It's almost dawn.
We arrived in Sydney as dawn broke (= as the first light could be seen).
I woke up just before dawn.
summer’s early dawns
He works from dawn till dusk (= from morning till night).
The plane took off, leaving London behind in a blue-grey dawn.
Dawn was breaking over the valley.
She awoke to another glorious dawn.
He always got up to greet the dawn.
It's almost dawn.
Be prepared for cold nights and foggy dawns in the mountains next week.
Ammunition was seized during a dawn raid on the house.

meanings.def: the beginning or first signs of something
examples: the dawn of civilization/time/history
Peace marked a new dawn in the country's history.
the dawn of a golden age in European art
We are seeing the dawn of a new era.
This sudden success may prove to be a false dawn.
This appointment marked the dawn of a productive era in her scientific career.
I have to get up at the crack of dawn.

meanings.def: the moment in the early hours of the morning when it begins to get light

examples: I have to get up at the crack of dawn.

idioms.def: the moment in the early hours of the morning when it begins to get light

examples: The following morning dawned bright and warm.
A new technological age had dawned.

meanings.def: to become obvious or easy to understand
examples: Slowly the awful truth dawned.

meanings.def: somebody suddenly understood or began to understand something
examples: I puzzled over the problem for ages before the light suddenly dawned.

idioms.def: somebody suddenly understood or began to understand something
examples: I puzzled over the problem for ages before the light suddenly dawned.
